intro: Silene inflata subsp. puberula, commonly known as the pubescent bladderpod, is a flowering plant native to arid and semi-arid regions of the southwestern United States. It is characterized by its hairy stems and leaves, which help reduce water loss in its harsh environment. The plant produces showy, pink to purple flowers that bloom in late spring to early summer. It is typically found in sandy or gravelly soils along dry streambeds and slopes. Silene inflata subsp. puberula is a member of the Caryophyllaceae family, known for its adaptations to drought and heat.
